review_title: Pay is too low for stress
pros: PTO policy is good. Management generally doesn’t micromanage.
cons:
No Maternity leave benefits except for private short term disability that barely functions when needed. 

CEO drives a Rolls Royce and Carilion is in a constant state of expensive expansion yet employees get small (1-3%) raises because “the company is non-profit and they can’t afford it.” 

Employees are generally expected to act well above job role but only when it’s convenient for management. 

Work/life balance is not good. The stress levels at Carilion are excessively high compared to the benefits and pay. I’m planning to leave the company next year. 

The company motto is to improve the health of the communities we serve, yet Carilion is the area’s largest employer and they don’t pay well or offer benefits like maternity leave, sick leave, etc.

Lots of different tech stacks so someone coming into the field can get their hands dirty with various different industry-standard tools pretty quickly.
Work environment can be relatively laid-back, depending on what team you work within. Choose wisely.

If you're clever and know how to play workplace politics, you can move up pretty quickly.
cons:
This might be a little long. Most of the issues boil down to extremely corporate, bureaucratic nonsense. 

To start, unless you're the most top-level of senior analysts/sysadmins/etc, you will not receive industry standard pay for your role. Job requirements for entry level positions are nearly laughable and are very clearly overstated. They often mix and match with hilariously disproportionate credentials such as "Masters degree required, network+ or *insert entry level Microsoft/ITIL cert here* as well". Senior individuals shouldn't be expected to have entry level certs like Network+. Realize the talents of people you have on hand.


If you expect to have management take any of your concerns about operations seriously, you're dreaming. With the exception of, well, 3-4 of them while I was there, they are simply warm bodies. You may be thinking "Well, 3 or 4 of the managers/directors is probably most of them!" Not even close - I'll touch on that below. They are the kings of "circling back" to important issues and NEVER making anyone get them done. The amount of pending projects and money spent on incomplete work is just unreal. It's like no one in executive leadership even cares what they're spending money on or how it's going to be executed. This leaves a massive amount of "clean-up" work being pushed onto a handful of key individuals within departments, while middle management provides lip service to non IT executives about the actual state of things. Since they don't have the technical knowledge to disprove the information they're giving, they're likely under the impression everything is totally fine.


Vendors completely walk all over everyone. No one will change contracts, despite whatever solution in place being riddled with issues. There's a few exceptions where it reached a boiling point and solutions were changed, but they're few and far between. Expect repeat, fixable problems to occur ad-nauseam until specific doctors making over a million dollars a year (no joke, go check the publicly available 990 forms) complain about it. Bonus points if they wake you up at 3 in the morning. 


With the exception of a handful of individuals, information security is not really taken seriously. Systems are left in vulnerable states for months (even years occasionally) at a time unless the issue is so egregious they have zero choice. The attention given is quite random and follows no real contextual priority system. It took a very long time to get simple, industry standard controls into place that should have been present 5-10 years prior. If this is something you value as a part of your M.O., I would probably look elsewhere.


You get a lot of PTO, but you'll never be able to take it all. I'm pretty sure they're aware of this as well, which is why they let you "cash-out" the PTO. This is actually cool, so I won't complain too much here, but the premise remains that you're not gonna get your full time off if your job has any sort of business-dependency. 


If you upset someone or have too much of a disagreement with someone who's above you in TSG or in a clinical role, despite no matter how correct you are, you WILL be railroaded out of there by HR. This didn't happen to me, but I personally did witness several individuals have the HR department weaponized against them when they rocked the boat a bit too much. This creates an openly malicious workplace environment for anyone who tries to speak up about potential ethical issues. Which there are many of.


Process-heavy CAB allows essentially nothing of real importance to get done at the urgency it needs to. In some cases, this is okay, as it does avoid potential issues. Most of the time it's just a way for non-technical leadership to try and insert themselves into technical issues to look important. This is incredibly obvious by the fact that specific changes, such as major networking infrastructure reworks, are ALWAYS immediately approved despite carrying higher risk than, say, someone changing a text field on a web application. Specific managers make a concerted effort to always involve themselves with changes that they have little knowledge of, and are by no means subject matter experts. Instead of deferring to said subject matter experts, their word is often taken at face value since they "talk the talk" well. Certain groups are given much more scrutiny than others, which follow no real pattern and are almost certainly arbitrary.


There's an ongoing joke within TSG that the solution to all problems they have is to hire more directors. The amount of bloat in middle-management is astonishing. Larger than any other place I've personally, or anyone else I personally know. This includes seasoned, veteran systems administrators with decades of experiences in similar size environments. It's like the joke from Office Space where Peter tells his interviewers that he has 8 bosses. There are, depending on your org chart and where you sit, more managers and directors over your department than actual teammates doing the real work. Some teams are randomly overstaffed, many are randomly understaffed. It follows no rhyme or reason.


Never expect low-performing, decadent, repeat-offender, and frankly, lazy employees to be disciplined in any sort of serious manner. I knew of an individual who had quite literally done 3 hours of work in an entire month, and it was proven to leadership that this was the case, and they still did nothing about it. In one instance, I witnessed an individual flagrantly and egregiously defying directives from leadership and without revealing too much information, was clearly not doing their job. Everyone knew this, including management, and it still took them 6 months before anything was done about it and they were separated from the company. Most other companies, the 2nd or 3rd instance of this type of behavior would have been met with swift action. Carilion, will quite literally forgive you for anything, unless you make them look bad externally or to clinical executives.


I'll wrap up with this - it's possible that every single concern I mentioned above has been fixed in the couple of years I've been gone, but I highly doubt it. I still speak with many of my former colleagues that presently work at Carilion and the consensus is business as usual.

cons: The ability for promotion within the department is nearly nonexistent and schedules are seldom consistent due to high turnover. The job itself is very very stressful and people burnout fast. Due to this team members quit frequently and the staffing needs fluctuate. You can expect to work holidays due the facility being a full service hospital. In addition pay is not competitive with less stressful positions of similar skill level offered at different organizations. Management is prone to wasting their budget on equipment that doesn't work and wasting time enforcing policy which has nothing to do with making the department more efficient. They also grade you every month on your performance using a lot of arbitrary statistics which can be easily gamed once you know how they're measured.

review_title: The Place to Be in Healthcare in SWVA
pros: If you want to work in healthcare in southwestern Virginia, then Carilion is where you want to be.  As a non-profit, they put a lot back into the community, and I feel that is a very important quality that makes me proud to work here.  As far as employment goes, they have a great time-off policy, as well as other wonderful employee benefits, such as educational assistance.  They also do a lot of promoting within, so once you get your foot in the door, there is a lot of opportunity to move up if you work hard enough and have the right attitude.  They are also one of the few companies nowadays that still offer a pension plan, so that is a definite bonus!
cons: I feel the pay in general could be a little bit more competitive with the rest of the state and nation, as well as wish that they offered retirement plan contribution matching opportunities.

pros: The unit that I work with promotes a great family sort of working atmosphere.  My manager is the best manager I have ever worked for.   I have learned a lot while working for Carilion.  Most doctors are approachable, the nurses are the best to work with.  Our Unit Director invites the staff to create opportunities for improvement for the customer experience as well as for workplace cohesiveness and moral boosting.
cons: Pay is not the most competitive.

pros: Level I Trauma Center - 16 years experience in the Neuro/Trauma ICU, (total of 20 years experience), great unit to gain knowledge, they do encourage continuing education.  Love working in this unit.
cons: No support from unit director/management, no communication, very quick to write people up for insignifcant things, too political, favoritism, evaluations are made public (notices are posted you can pick vacations due to your eval, policy states first come first serve)  Very high turnover rate due to management, Director w/little experience RN for only 3 years.  Unit Director talks down to staff, at nurse's station, belittles staff ,  very accusatory/reactive personality.  New staff members are afraid to say anything because they are intimidated.

pros: On the cutting edge of technology. Will spend the money to be the most up to date and have the best systems and software on the market.
cons: Care less for their employees. Expect the best and reward for nothing. Require you to go above and beyond what is normally expected but fail to inspire or commend you for what you have done. Have no problem cutting benefits and pay but still want the same productivity all the while spending tons and tons of money on un-justified expenses. Extremely top heavy in management. Increase in healthcare, elimination of retirement contribution and low cap of merit increases if any.

pros: This place is on the border of being a great job.  Like all places, management could use some management.  Hard to get fired (this could be a bad thing).  There are moments of down time and you can run errands while on the clock.  They help pay for school.  You can educate yourself in all levels of EMS and they will provide the means.
cons: The companies benefits are crap.  No matching 401k. Pension is minuscule and takes 5 years to become vested.  Health insurance has gone way up and in monopolistic requiring you to only use their providers (should be illegal).   No real kudos for when you go above and beyond.  Don't hurt yourself or get sick, they will probably just fire you.  And don't mention the word union.

pros: Better health benefits than most hospitals except that you are confined to using Carilion facilities when available.
cons: Low pay for nurses. I make twice the amount when I take a travel job occasionally. No matching of 403b, not enough nurses to staff floor properly causing unsafe conditions for patients.

Effective management requires education and experience that is specific to business; this cannot be substituted by simply working within the same company before being "promoted" when a job opens.

job_title: Pharmacy Operations Manager in Roanoke, VA
pros: I was recruited to Carilion Clinic 10 years ago.  Since it would require relocating my family more than 750 miles from our home I knew the position and community would have to meet all of our expectations and it has.  Carilion Clinic Inpatient Pharmacy is a department that has highly qualified pharmacists and technicians and we're providing acute care pharmacy services at a very high level. review_title: Great place to work, focused on the mission
pros:
I worked at Carilion for four years. Almost everyone I worked with - clinical or otherwise - was enthusiastic about the work, largely out of a desire to care for our patients and communities. People saw their job as either directly or indirectly serving their families, friends, neighbors, etc. who walked through our doors.  Team members here truly lived the organization's stated values too. Working through tough strategic and operational problems is far easier with that sort of alignment.

People at Carilion were on the whole quite creative, eager to solve problems, and willing to go "above and beyond" if it helps our patients. Most staff I worked with were laid-back and friendly too; it reflected well on Southwest VA. It was an easy place to build good professional relationships.

Salary, benefits, etc. were competitive for the market. Work life balance was quite good for a large healthcare system, at least on the business/administrative end where I worked. PTO and retirement benefits were particularly solid.

Tools and technology on the business side were not ideal, but better than many other healthcare organizations (the industry usually lags others in this area).

The organization was quick to highlight outstanding work by team members, particularly in areas like quality, safety, or patient-centric care. 

Carilion was also pretty forward-thinking as a healthcare organization, despite not being in a market where reimbursement pushed it to do so. Senior management was frequently open to trying new approaches, even if just to learn on a small scale.
cons:
Carilion is a large organization, with that comes the inevitable bureaucracy, siloes, and communication challenges. Change did not always happen fast, and various parts of the organization were sometimes caught unaware of what others were up to.

Team members were full of ideas. Unfortunately that enthusiasm sometimes led to competing projects, communication issues, strong pressure for scope creep, and demand bottlenecks among the IT, finance, analytics, and other shared services staff responsible for supporting projects. Better coordination and prioritization of initiatives is essential. Senior leadership was working on this when I departed.

Carilion expanded rapidly over a 15-year period. Many site and practices retain elements of their pre-Carilion selves. This preserves some good elements of their cultures (e.g. the neighborly feel in our rural hopsitals) but can also make Carilion  feel like a loose alliance rather than a true health system.  Senior management exacerbates this sometimes by being too "Roanoke-centric", i.e. focusing on the big tertiary medical center to the extent it assumes what works for RMH/CMC will work for other sites.

Physician alignment with health system goals was a work in progress when I was there, due in part to the rapid acquisitions described above. 

There were disconnects (as exists in most health systems) between administration / clinical leadership and front line clinical staff, who were frequently unaware of major priorities. There were also disconnects between Carilion (historically a community health system used to running lean and moving relatively quickly) and the increasing alignment with Virginia Tech School of Medicine (academia loves process, rigor, and gold-plated solutions).

Lastly, the senior leadership team preferred a "read and react" approach rather than committing to strategic plans. This gave Carilion tremendous agility, but made it hard for leaders and staff to prioritize projects.

pros: Lots of job security at Carilion. Lots of opportunity to move positions once you get your foot in the door.  Really good PTO, you earn almost 5 weeks a year starting out.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Roanoke, VA
pros: I really enjoy working for the company Carilion Clinic as a whole. Because how fast paced and busy the job usually is, will make the day fly by. There usually is a lot of opportunity for overtime in this position. The training for the job was extremely helpful. Coworkers get along great. Health insurance is good. Pay is not bad, but I would not recommend due to the stress level of the job.
cons: I will start off by saying the employee's do not get paid well enough for what they have to put up with in this position. Pay is not competitive at all to less stressful positions that require the same skill and knowledge level. Management for the department is not easy to get along with, rather the opposite. Manager comes off very rude and sometimes a bully to the employees, and hardly ever gives lunch breaks due to "being short staffed". There is a lot of office talk regarding the stress level of this job and how it affects their daily lives.  Everyone complains constantly about how much they hate the job. Manager does not care about you work/life balance at all, wants you to put this job first above all your personal needs and life at all times even if you are sick or have kids or health conditions that require medical treatment. It is extremely hard to get time off in this position unless you call out and use one of your 4-5 occurrences for the year. There always is a need for "mandatory overtime" where the manager makes all the employees work at LEAST 2-3 hours of overtime per week. The turnover rate is tremendous, and the department is always short staffed. Manager says she is not allowed to hire more people and we have to make do with the amount of staff we have (which is NOT enough for the work load). Some of the employees are made to work 12-16 hour shifts almost every day that have babies and kids at home. You get called in a lot on your days off asking for you to come in because of the extreme amount of work load they put on the employees, and if you decline to come in, they mark it against you. This job is NOT for you if you have absolutely any kind of life outside of work and/or if you have friends/family/kids/pets that you care to spend time with outside of the job. You basically have to "eat, sleep, and breath" Patient Access in order to work for this department.

review_title: IT/TSG Department - Do I have to give One Star?
pros:
The Staff - They do all they can with what tools they have to keep things together.

The Clients - They care for patients and keep us showing up for work to support them.
cons:
Is anyone listening from above? How many negative reviews from one department are required before anyone looks?

HR came in to talk to "random staff" a few months back when a policy change with communicated to the department in very unprofessional terms. The result from HR's "investigation" was clearly staff were not paying attention to how great all the changes are so everyone had to go through a new round of re-education on the changes. How was this decision made? Is there some latitude granted because we report through the EVP over HR?

Work/Life balance is work until you are out of life.

There is some clear disconnect between leadership and experienced staff. The answer from leadership is "some people can't handle change well" but you don't work in IT and not know how to experience and accept change. The number and quality of senior resources leaving this department is scary.

"assignment buckets" that simplify things replaced a functional process that involved automated routing and a couple of minutes/day for each leader and they redesigned it so all inbound requests have to be touched ? times before someone actually is assigned to the work. By that point, the client has been waiting for weeks/months and is out of patience to work with someone trying to resolve their request.

Top Heavy Management Structure. 

Insane spending habits. Does anyone even look at what the IT department spends their money on? 

Corporate-Wide - How many consulting companies are working to "improve" the organization right now?
